project_name: New Residential Accessory Building for Dave & Cory Matthews
gravity_system: Pre-Engineered Attic Trusses, 2x8 Floor Joists, CMU Walls, Concrete Footings
other_materials: Plywood, OSB Sheathing, Rigid Insulation, Batt Insulation, Metal Roofing
structural_trusses: Pre-Engineered Attic Trusses, Pre-Engineered Scissor Trusses
key_elements: Floating Slab, CMU Walls, Pre-Engineered Trusses, Gasproofing, Loft
overall_building_description: The building's structural integrity is achieved through a combination of pre-engineered attic trusses and scissor trusses, which provide the primary roof support, ensuring efficient load distribution across the structure. The trusses are designed to accommodate a 10-inch heel height, facilitating adequate insulation and ventilation, critical for maintaining thermal efficiency and preventing moisture accumulation. The roof assembly incorporates pre-finished metal waterproofing membranes over 1/2-inch roofing plywood, with 'H' clips ensuring structural stability and preventing deflection. The roof plan mandates vented soffits and a 1 1/2-inch venting space between sheathing and insulation, utilizing Morvents to enhance airflow and prevent condensation. The foundation system employs a floating slab design, reinforced with 6x6x6/6 welded wire mesh at mid-depth, and a thickened edge measuring 1-foot wide by 1-foot 6-inches thick, reinforced with continuous 15M rebar. This configuration ensures the slab's ability to withstand differential settlement and provides a robust base for the CMU walls. The CMU walls, constructed with two rows of 6-inch concrete masonry units, are reinforced with 15M rebar embedded into the slab at 48 inches on center, providing lateral stability and resistance to shear forces. The exterior walls are framed with 2x6 studs at 16 inches on center, sheathed with 7/16-inch OSB, and insulated with R20 batt insulation, ensuring compliance with energy efficiency standards. The walls are further protected with a 6-mil poly vapor barrier and finished with 1/2-inch drywall, taped and sanded to ensure a smooth finish. The building's interior partitions utilize 2x4 studs at 16 inches on center, with similar drywall finishes, maintaining consistency in construction quality. The loft floor assembly features 3/4-inch tongue and groove sheathing, screwed and glued to the floor joists, providing a stable and durable walking surface. The loft plan emphasizes the importance of gasproofing between the garage and dwelling areas, utilizing 1/2-inch drywall to prevent the ingress of hazardous gases. The building section reveals a comprehensive integration of structural components, with the top of the concrete floor set at 1-foot 6-inches above the footing, ensuring adequate clearance and protection from moisture ingress. The section also highlights the use of concrete footings, designed to distribute loads evenly to the underlying soil, with a bearing capacity of 1500 psf for undisturbed soil conditions. The assembly schedule provides detailed specifications for each component, ensuring adherence to design criteria and facilitating efficient construction sequencing. The project complies with the Ontario Building Code, with specific references to concrete cover requirements, rebar splice lengths, and insulation standards, ensuring the building's safety and performance. The construction process mandates the submission of pre-engineered truss drawings to the building department prior to site inspection, ensuring compliance with design intent and facilitating smooth project execution. The assembly sequence emphasizes the importance of verifying dimensions and suitability before manufacturing trusses, preventing costly errors and ensuring structural integrity. The project incorporates site-specific considerations, such as the removal of topsoil and organic material from the building area, and the use of compacted granular fill in 6-inch lifts to achieve the desired grade, ensuring a stable and durable foundation. The building's design prioritizes energy efficiency, with extensive use of rigid insulation and air barriers, minimizing heat loss and enhancing occupant comfort. The use of ACQ-rated fasteners in treated wood applications ensures longevity and resistance to corrosion, maintaining the structural integrity of the building over its lifespan.
